description: First attested in the mid-15th century. From Middle English cynabare, from Old French cinabre, from Latin cinnabaris, from Ancient Greek κιννάβαρι (kinnábari), from perhaps Arabic زِنْجَفْر‎ (zinjafr), related to Persian شنگرف‎ (šangarf) from Old Persian 𐎿𐎡𐎣𐎲𐎽𐎢𐏁 (s-i-k-b-ru-u-š /sinkabruš/, “carnelian”), of unknown origin.

adjectives.description: cinnabar (comparative more cinnabar, superlative most cinnabar)

entries.meaning: Of a bright red colour tinted with orange.
A deep red mineral, mercuric sulfide, HgS; the principal ore of mercury; such ore used as the pigment vermilion.
A bright red colour tinted with orange.
(countable) A species of moth, Tyria jacobaeae, having red patches on its predominantly black wings.
